awd_abstract_narration:
This award will fund the 2017 MINDS (Mentoring for Innovative Design Solutions) Workshop organized by Alpha Eta Mu Beta, the National Biomedical Engineering Honors Society.  The workshop will be held October 11-14 in Phoenix, AZ, in parallel with the BMES 2017 Annual Meeting.  This will allow the students selected for the MINDS Scholar Program to also participate in the BMES Annual Meeting.  The  MINDS Scholar Program is an innovative approach that provides students with the opportunity to collaborate and network with peers and mentors across the country for a 5-month period, while building necessary engineering design skills, including three key considerations that are not usually stressed in coursework projects. The three key considerations are: (1) market considerations for commercialization (unmet need, size of market reimbursement potential, etc.), (2) regulatory strategy, and (3) evaluating prospects for intellectual property protection.  The program begins with an initial workshop where students meet their team members, drawn from other universities across the US, and mentors.  The team then selects a central design idea that will be developed over the subsequent 5 months.  Students will be selected through a competitive process, with junior undergraduates preferred.  Students will then work with their teams and mentors to develop a design solution that takes into account issues such as market evaluation, intellectual property issues, and regulation.  Subject matter experts will provide support to the teams during this 5 month design period.  Teams will be encouraged to submit their designs to various design contests, investment opportunities, and grant programs.  This program will develop a core group of engineers who will better understand the importance of considering human needs before attempting to design devices, and who will be more likely to engage in a variety of activities that improve the human condition.  Moreover, the participants will learn how to assess human needs and will effectively use the key design considerations that are of paramount importance for successful translation of ideas to the marketplace so that they can truly help people. Additionally, the collaborative and long-distance communication skills that they develop in this project will better equip them to work in an environment that is increasingly dependent on communication between distant facilities and customers.
  

The majority of design courses in the US, particularly in biomedical engineering programs, do not have sufficient time to provide students with a strong experience in the non-technical aspects that are key to design success: market potential, intellectual property, and regulation.  This program will provide seven teams of three students, selected through a competitive process from across the US, with key experience related to real world design processes for medical systems.  It will also provide students with significant experience in working on a geographically separated team and with peers from varied backgrounds, both of which are strongly valued by industry.

por.por_cntn:
Alpha Eta Mu Beta (AHMB) is the international biomedical engineering honor society, and it was established to recognize and encourage excellence in the field of Biomedical Engineering and Bioengineering, and to promote a greater understanding of the profession. AHMB's "Mentoring for INnovative Design Solutions" (MINDS) Scholar Program is an innovative approach that provides biomedical engineering students with the opportunity to collaborate and network with peers and mentors across the country for a 5-month period, while building necessary engineering design skills. Although students learn about the design process in their college coursework, there are several areas that are not always sufficiently emphasized in a typical engineering program, for instance (1) market considerations for commercialization (why is this product needed, what market is there for it, how big is the market expected to be, etc.),  (2) regulatory strategy (what regulations does the product need to meet in order to be approved for sale, and how can the design team plan for a successful strategy to get their product approved), and (3) evaluating prospects for intellectual property protection (how can the design team protect others from using their idea or copying their product).

Having these skills is very important for future engineers in order to be able to design products that can successfully reach the public. In order for biomedical engineers to address public healthcare needs, they need to have the knowledge and skills to navigate every step and aspect of bringing a product to market. During the program, MINDS Scholars enhance their knowledge of product design, but they also learn how to effectively communicate with teammates and mentors from other schools and organizations using collaborative online tools, which are becoming an increasingly important skill in today's work environment.

Participation in the MINDS Scholar Program is through a competitive application process, and students need not be AHMB members to participate, as all biomedical engineering majors are eligible. Each annual MINDS Scholar Program starts with an in-person workshop, where students meet their team members and mentors, and create an action plan for their participation in the program. They select a central design idea that will be refined during the 5-month period, and then they periodically communicate to advance the project forward, culminating in a final report in the form of a website, a presentation, or a written report.

In the 2017-2018 program, there were 23 students (22 completed) and 13 mentors. By the end of the program, participants were able to create a novel product idea, describe how they used the key design considerations in the design process, and state the features, benefits and impacts of their products through production of a promotional presentation. Product ideas varied widely and included a low-cost incubator, a washable sanitary wheelchair cover, a microfluidic device for point-of-care diagnostics, a smart salivary pacifier monitor, a viral-bacterial biosensor, a bandage for automatic wound monitoring, and a neonatal incubating waterbed.

Students were surveyed at the beginning and the end of the program. A majority of students agreed or highly agreed that the MINDS program had improved their perceived skills in understanding the design considerations addressed in the program and applying them to any project, assessing product requirements, explaining key features of a project, collaborating remotely, and working in a team. Many students also reported that MINDS impacted their career goals. The results of the 2017-2018 program, and feedback from students and mentors, were used to improve the program for future cohorts.

Some quotes from 2017-2018 students were as follows:

MINDS really impacted my design thinking skills. It trained me to be able to analyze problems and find solutions.

MINDS has definitely helped me to work on my time management skills, as well as to improve my communication and remote work skills.

MINDS was an excellent longitudinal experience in group work - we experienced the entire arc of a design project in five months [...] I was able to take a critical look at my own leadership skills as the project progressed.

It helped me realize the thought you need to put into a product in order to reach a certain market.

 The hard part is finding a way to make that idea different from the rest [...] you have to innovate and make it your own. This helps us become better engineers [..] better troubleshooters, problem solvers, creators, etc.

I loved the collaborative environment and the resources the mentors provided us with. I learned the most when our mentor brought in experts in certain fields related to designing a product.

In summary, we achieved our aims of teaching students how to integrate market needs, regulatory considerations, and intellectual property strategy into the design process. In doing this, we also increased their awareness of how biomedical devices and technologies can benefit society.
